title: 113_s2952
content: The "Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2014" establishes the Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking in the executive branch. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking is comprised of 15 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Appointments include individuals with expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, and privacy matters. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by various leaders, including those with expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, and privacy matters. Appointments are made by the President, Speaker of the House of Representatives, Minority Leader of the House, Majority Leader of the Senate, and Minority Leader of the Senate. Members appointed by the House and Senate leaders include academic researchers, data experts, and individuals with expertise in database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by various leaders, including those with expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, and privacy matters. Appointments are made by the President, Speaker of the House of Representatives, Minority Leader of the House, Majority Leader of the Senate, and Minority Leader of the Senate. Members appointed by the House and Senate leaders include academic researchers, data experts, and individuals with expertise in database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. The President selects the chairperson, and the Speaker of the House of Representatives selects the co-chairperson. Appointments to the Commission must be made within 45 days of the enactment of the Act, and each member serves for the duration of the Commission with vacancies being filled promptly. Members of the Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking serve without pay and are allowed travel expenses for their services. Vacancies in the Commission do not affect its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Vacancies do not affect its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will conduct a study on data inventory, infrastructure, and protocols related to Federal policymaking. Recommendations will be made on integrating data for program evaluation and research, modifying infrastructure, and incorporating outcomes measurement. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will consider creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data, including evaluation of relevant administrative datasets, survey dataset linkages, legal barriers, and data-sharing infrastructure. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will explore creating a self-funded clearinghouse for research data, determining access for qualified researchers, setting limitations on data use, ensuring privacy, using data to inform policymakers, and incentivizing interagency data sharing. Upon agreement by three-quarters of the Commission members, a detailed report will be submitted to the President and Congress. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will submit a detailed report to the President and Congress with findings, recommendations for legislation or administrative actions, and a deadline of 15 months after the majority of Commission members are appointed. The term "administrative data" refers to information generated or collected by an agency in carrying out a Federal program. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will have specific operations and powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will receive administrative assistance from various government agencies and must hold meetings within 30 days of appointing a majority of its members. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking will establish rules of procedure, hold hearings, and may contract with government or private agencies to carry out its duties. It can also use the United States mails for communication purposes. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking can use the United States mails and accept gifts or donations. The Director of the Census can contract with the National Academy of Public Administration for administration. Funding for the Commission is provided by principal statistical agencies, not to exceed $2,000,000. The term "statistical agency" is defined in a report by the Office of Management and Budget titled "Statistical Programs of the United States Government, Fiscal Year 2014". The Commission established shall have a Director appointed by the chairperson and co-chairperson, with staff appointed as needed. Experts and consultants may be hired at specified rates. The Commission will terminate within 18 months of the Act's enactment.
